importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The game took place on October 17, 2025, highlighting an aging NFL quarterback rivalry and reinforcing the relevance of veteran athletes in modern sports.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The event occurred during the Thursday Night Football schedule, showcasing how veteran quarterbacks remain competitive in the NFL despite age.

keyTakeAways: Joe Flacco and Aaron Rodgers, both over 40, delivered high-level performances in a physically demanding game, proving that age does not necessarily diminish performance in professional sports.
The Bengals defeated the Steelers 33-31 in a tightly contested match known as the 'Icy Hot Bowl', with Flacco throwing for 342 yards and three touchdowns.
Flacco, making his second start with the Bengals after injuries to Joe Burrow and Jake Browning, led a crucial two-minute drive to secure the win.
Rodgers threw for four touchdowns and two interceptions, and surpassed Ben Roethlisberger to become the fifth all-time leading passer in NFL history.
The game featured a dramatic final sequence where the Steelers had a chance to tie with seven seconds left, but Flacco's final drive resulted in a game-winning field goal.
The Bengals improved to 3-4 on the season, while the Steelers fell to 4-2 and remain atop the AFC North.
Offensive stars Ja’Marr Chase and Tee Higgins had standout performances, with Chase catching 16 passes for 161 yards and rushing for over 100 yards for the first time in the season.
The game was dubbed 'Icy Hot Bowl' by Steelers teammate Cameron Heyward, reflecting the contrast of cold weather and intense competition between two veteran quarterbacks.

namedEntities.name: Joe Flacco
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, now with the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Flacco, at 40 years old, led a high-impact performance in a crucial win over the Steelers, demonstrating the continued viability of veteran quarterbacks in the NFL.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Rodgers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former NFL quarterback, with the Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers, at 41, delivered a strong game and surpassed Ben Roethlisberger to move into fifth place on the NFL's all-time career passing yards list.

namedEntities.name: Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bengals won a critical game against the Steelers, with Flacco's performance helping them maintain their season momentum despite injuries to key players.

namedEntities.name: Pittsburgh Steelers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Steelers lost to the Bengals in a close game, falling to 4-2 and remaining in contention in the AFC North despite a strong performance by Rodgers.

namedEntities.name: Cameron Heyward
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Heyward coined the nickname 'Icy Hot Bowl' for the game, emphasizing the intensity and contrast of the matchup between veteran quarterbacks.

namedEntities.name: Joe Burrow
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Flacco was brought in as a replacement after Burrow suffered a long-term toe injury, highlighting the importance of depth and adaptability in NFL rosters.

namedEntities.name: Jake Browning
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Browning’s poor debut performance prompted Flacco’s move to the Bengals, showing how injuries and performance gaps impact team strategies.

namedEntities.name: Ja’Marr Chase
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chase had a breakout performance with 16 catches for 161 yards and a season-high rushing effort, contributing significantly to the Bengals' win.

namedEntities.name: Tee Higgins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Higgins recorded six catches for 96 yards, a season high, and contributed to the Bengals’ offensive success.

namedEntities.name: Noah Fant
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Fant caught a touchdown in the game, adding to Flacco’s three-touchdown output and demonstrating the team’s depth.

namedEntities.name: Chase Brown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brown rushed for over 100 yards for the first time in the season, marking a breakout performance for the running game.

namedEntities.name: Evan McPherson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: McPherson converted the game-winning field goal in the final minutes, sealing the Bengals’ 33-31 victory.

namedEntities.name: Ben Roethlisberger
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Steelers quarterback and NFL career passing leader
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers surpassed Roethlisberger to move into fifth place on the NFL's all-time passing yards list, marking a historic moment for the Steelers and NFL history.

namedEntities.name: Brett Favre
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodgers is still behind Favre in career passing yards, showing that while Rodgers has achieved a milestone, the NFL’s all-time record remains a significant benchmark.

namedEntities.name: Zac Taylor
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Head coach of the Cincinnati Bengals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Taylor praised Flacco’s composure and leadership, especially in the critical final drive, underscoring the coaching staff’s trust in veteran quarterback performance.

namedEntities.name: NFL
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article reflects on the NFL’s evolving landscape, where veteran athletes continue to play at a high level, challenging the notion that the league is exclusively a 'young man’s game'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a high-stakes Thursday Night Football matchup dubbed the 'Icy Hot Bowl', 40-year-old Joe Flacco outperformed 41-year-old Aaron Rodgers in a dramatic 33-31 win for the Cincinnati Bengals over the Pittsburgh Steelers. Despite Rodgers surpassing Ben Roethlisberger to move into fifth place on the NFL’s all-time career passing yards list, Flacco’s steady performance—throwing for 342 yards and three touchdowns, including a crucial two-minute drive that ended with a game-winning field goal—proved decisive. The Bengals, who had lost their starting quarterback to injury and relied on Flacco’s experience, remained competitive with strong performances from Ja’Marr Chase and Tee Higgins, while Chase Brown had his first 100-yard rushing game. The Steelers, though hampered by a late touchdown from Rodgers, fell to 4-2 and remain atop the AFC North. The game underscored the continued relevance and excellence of veteran players in the NFL, challenging age-based assumptions about athletic performance.
title: Joe Flacco outduels Aaron Rodgers in battle of elder statesmen as Bengals stun Steelers in ‘Icy Hot Bowl’
